Brønsted acidic hydrogensulfate ionic liquid immobilized SBA-15: [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 as an environmentally friendly, metal- and halogen-free recyclable catalyst for Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization processes Sadegh Rostamnia a ⁎ Asadollah Hassankhani b ⁎ Habib Golchin Hossieni a Behnam Gholipour a Hongchuan Xin c ⁎ a Organic & Nano Group (ONG), Department of Chemistry, University of Maragheh, PO Box, 55181-83111 Maragheh, Iran Organic & Nano Group (ONG), Department of Chemistry, University of Maragheh PO Box Maragheh 55181-83111 Iran b Department of New Materials, Institute of Science and High Technology and Environmental Sciences, Graduate University of Advanced Technology, PO Box, 76315-117 Kerman, Iran Department of New Materials, Institute of Science and High Technology and Environmental Sciences, Graduate University of Advanced Technology PO Box Kerman 76315-117 Iran c Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China ⁎ Corresponding authors’ at: University of Maragheh, Organic & Nano Group (ONG), Department of Chemistry, PO Box, Madar SQ, Maragheh 55181-83111, Iran. Tel.: +98 4212278001 108/+989124338696; fax: +98 421 2276066. Graphical abstract The Brønsted acidic imidazolium-based metal-free and halogen-free ionic liquid hydrogen sulfate was immobilized on nanoporous silica SBA-15. The structures of synthesized catalysts were investigated using different characterization techniques, including FT-IR, small angle XRD, SEM, TEM and TGA. The [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 is used as an alternative to conventional catalysts in the Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization processes for the synthesis of tetrahydrochromenes and hexahydroquinoline carboxylates via a multicomponent procedure. The reaction time is reduced drastically and the reaction is progressed in an environmentally friendly way. The immobilized catalyst can be recycled without substantial loss of activity after seven runs. Keywords Hydrogensulfate ionic liquid SBA-15 Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization Tetrahydrochromenes Hexahydroquinoline carboxylates 1 Introduction The development of sustainable chemical transformations with high efficacy and low waste is an important goal in green chemistry and environmental sciences [1]. Since the water-medium organic reaction could reduce the pollution and cost resulting from organic solvents and simultaneously facilitate the separation of the catalyst from the products, the utilization of heterogeneous catalysts for organic process has emerged as a highly promising approach to attain in green chemistry [2]. Among various water-medium catalytic systems, the use of immobilized H+-acids function as catalysts is more challenging because conventional Brønsted acids such as HClO4, HBF4 and H2SO4 immobilization always have interaction with water rather than the substrates, resulting in serious leaching of the H+ from the surface of solid catalyst [1–3]. In recent years, organic transformations using supported ionic liquids (ILs) as reusable catalyst has received extensive attention [4]. The design and development of new and novel ILs that are air and moisture stable have provided renewed vigor in ionic liquid chemistry, and the emerging use of these ILs will be considered first. Immobilization of the ILs provides vaporless, thermally stable and ‘green’ auxiliary substances for chemical reactions [4,5]. The key issue in IL/solid system is effective immobilization of ILs onto solid to avoid the loss of ILs. Since some organic reactions normally uses H+-acids function as the catalyst, if the H+ can be effectively immobilized in IL/solid systems as counter ions, it would then be possible to enable the efficient separation and recycling of H+-catalyst in the reaction cycles [3–5]. On the other hand, Immobilization of the ILs into the mesoporous nanomaterials such as SBA-15 (IL@SBA-15) has gained increasing attention in replacement of the conventional mineral amorphous silica materials because of their high surface area, low densities, high thermal and mechanical stability during reaction processes [6]. One exceptional advantage is that the location of organic groups in the pores of SBA-15 allows for molecular-level fine-tuning of the host microenvironment. It is especially advantageous for water-medium organic transformations since the hydrophobic support microenvironment could concentrate the substrates (organic molecules as hosts) and decrease diffusion limitation to facilitate the reaction processes [6,7]. Previously, we developed synthetic methods for the synthesis of biologically interesting organic molecules [8]. The challenge in this field was the development of efficient and rapid green methods [6]. Moreover, the synthesis of these molecules has usually been carried out in hazardous and polar solvents such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, C6H6, DMF and DMSO, leading to complex isolation and recovery procedures. Recently, we synthesized a series of organic–inorganic hybrid heterogeneous catalysts, which displayed comparable activity and selectivity to those of homogenous system in a wide range of water medium organic reactions [6–8]. Encouraged by these successful efforts and aiming to develop a stable and highly active porous solid H+-catalyst in water, herein we report the synthesis of [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 catalysts. The [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 showed superior catalytic reactivity and selectivity in water-medium multicomponent coupling procedure for synthesis of tetrahydrochromenes and hexahydroquinoline carboxylates as a model organic reaction (Fig. 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and characterization Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS), 3-(chloropropyl)trimethoxysilane (MeO)3SiPrCl), triblock copolymer P123 (EO70PO20EO70) and other reagents were obtained from Aldrich, Merck (Germany) and Fluka (Switzerland) and used as received. Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus. The IR spectra were determined using a FT-IR Bruker–Vector 22. Progress of reactions was monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC). 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AV-500 instrument (500MHz) with DMSO-d 6 or CDCl3 as solvent. 2.2 Synthesis of SBA-15 and IL-immobilized SBA-15 SBA-15 was synthesized and purified according to our previous reported procedure [7]. The obtained mesoporous silica was then incorporated with imidazolium hydrogen sulfate as [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 by two methods. As shown in Fig. 2 , for procedure A, in a typical procedure to achieve [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15, to a suspension of SBA-15 (2g) in dry toluene, 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane ((MeO)3SiPrCl, 1mmol) was added, and the resulting mixture was refluxed for 24h under an inert atmosphere. Then the obtained SBA-15/PrCl was reacted with N-methylimidazole (1.5mmol) at 90°C for 20h in dry toluene. Finally, the [MPIm]Cl@SBA-15 (IL-Cl@SBA-15) solid product was filtered, and then dried under vacuum. The resultant IL-Cl@SBA-15 was transferred to the ion exchange column containing 0.5M H2SO4 for 5h. After that the solid products of [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 (IL-HSO4@SBA-15) were filtered, washed with distilled water (×3 with sonication) and finally dried in vacuum line at 60°C. Loading of the H+ of this IL@SBA-15 was 0.7mmol SO4Hg−1. The IL-HSO4@SBA-15 by procedure B was synthesized by taking N-methylimidazole (1mmol) and chloropropyl silane ((MeO)3SiPrCl) in 1:1 molar ratio by keeping it at 110°C for 24h under nitrogen atmosphere. The obtained IL of trimethylsilylpropyl methylimidazole [TmspMIm]Cl was dissolved in 100mL toluene at room temperature followed by addition of 2g of SBA-15 under vigorous stirring until clear solution is obtained. After refluxing for 24h, the filtered solid was transferred to the ion exchange column similar to procedure A. After that the solid products were filtered, washed with ethanol and finally dried at 60°C. To an aqueous solution of NaCl (1M, 25mL) with a primary pH 5.99, the IL-HSO4@SBA-15 (500mg) was added and the resulting mixture was stirred for 10min (under sonication). This method showed that the loading of the H+ for IL-HSO4@SBA-15 was 0.7mmolg−1. It is to note here that when we decided to perform ion exchange over the [TmspMIm]Cl to achieve IL-HSO4@SBA-15, the [TmspMIm]Cl hydrolysis was done (Fig. 2). 2.3 Typical procedure for preparation of compounds 3a and 5a A mixture of IL-SO4H@SBA-15 (synthesized by procedure A, 5mol%) and H2O (3mL), malononitrile [or β-dicarbonyl compound] (1.2mmol), benzaldehyde (1.0mmol) and dimedone (1.0mmol) was stirred at 40°C for appropriate time (Tables 2 and 3). The reaction progress was monitored by TLC as well as by the extended precipitation of the products from the reaction mixture. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated (by adding hot ethanol). Finally the mixture was recrystallized with EtOAc or ethanol. All products were known and characterized by comparison of their physical and spectra data with those already reported (see Supporting information). 2.3.1 2-amino-4-(furan-2-yl)-7,7-dimethyl-5-oxo-5,6,7,8-tetrahydro-4H-chromene-3-carbonitrile (3b) White solid. Mp: 206–208°C. IR (KBr v max/cm−1): 3396, 3327, 3214, 2196 (CN), 1661, 1365cm−1. 1H NMR (500.13MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ =1.2 (3H, s, 3H of CH3), 1.3 (3H, s, 3H of CH3), 2.2 (1H, d, 2 J HH =15.5Hz, 2H of CH2), 2.3 (1H, d, 2 J HH =15.4Hz, 2H of CH2), 2.6 (2H, m, 2H of CH2), 4.5 (1H, s, 1H of CH), 6.1 (1H, s, 1H of CH), 6.4 (1H, s, 1H of CH), 7.2 (2H, s, 2H of NH2), 7.5 (1H, s, 1H of CH). 2.4 Catalyst characterizations In the FT-IR spectra, the band from 807 and ∼1100cm−1 belongs to the vibrations of (SiOSi) bond, and the small band at about ∼980cm−1 is assigned to functionalized (SiOH) bond and the SiOH groups are shown by the very broad IR absorption band in the 3000–3700cm−1 region (Fig. 3a–c). For sulfuric acid functional group (Fig. 3c), the broad SOH stretching absorption lies in around 3570cm−1. SO stretchings appear at 950cm−1, double bonded SO stretchings fall in the 1100–1350cm−1 range (1070) and additional bands at 2920, 2850 and 1450cm−1 are due to CH stretching and deformation vibrations of the imidazole moiety and alkyl chain [7b]. Fig. 4 shows images of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of the as-synthesized SBA-15 sample. The highly ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15 observed by small-angle XRD, was confirmed by TEM images (Fig. 4c and d). Diffraction peaks at the below 2° corresponding to the (100), (110), and (200) are readily recognized from the XRD pattern of SBA-15 (Fig. 4e). The observed diffraction peaks agree with the 2-d-hexagonal SBA-15 family [7]. In fact, Fig. 2c and d shows the long-chain structure characteristic of the SBA-15 materials as it can be observed by the presence of straight mesochannels arraying along the long axis. It is important to note that, after the multi-step loading of organic groups and ionic liquid and even after 11th recycling, the highly ordered structure of the SBA-15 support was well retained (Fig. 4c–e). The average mesopore size estimated by TEM was around 6.4nm. To examine the thermal stability of the IL-HSO4@SBA-15, thermal gravimetric (TG) was carried out between 25°C and 800°C in a static atmosphere of nitrogen (Fig. 5 ). TG analysis of IL-HSO4@SBA-15 shows a weight loss due to the desorption of water below 100°C followed by a second weight loss centered at 140°C which is owing to the loss of inner water as well as the loss of CH3OH upon the further condensation of unreacted methoxy groups. This is finally followed by a set of weight losses centered at 385°C corresponding to the elimination of the surface bound organic propyl methylimidazole hydrogensulfate groups ([MPIm][HSO4]), which indicates that this immobilized hybrid catalyst (synthesized based on procedure A) is thermally stable up to 385°C. 3 Results and discussion In our previous developed methods for the synthesis of organic polar molecules using SBA-15 family catalysts [7], the big challenge was the mass transfer of organic substrates into the catalyst center within the SBA-15 channel. Based on our recent success on the preparation of hybrid organic–inorganic SBA-15 materials with lipophile pore-wall in presence of the ultrasonic irradiation as a mass transfer accelerator [6b,7a], here, we present the results of an extended investigation on the activity of the imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ionic liquid immobilized SBA-15 nanoreactor (IL-HSO4@SBA-15) as a green hybrid catalyst. The catalytic capability of the IL-HSO4@SBA-15 in a domino Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization process leading to the formation of tetrahydro-4H-chromenes and polyhydroquinolines without using any salts or additives was investigated. First, the condensation of benzaldehyde, dimedone and malononitrile was selected as a model system (Table 1 ). By screening a wide range of H+-sources, we found that product 3a could be obtained in yields ranging from 17 to 60% using various solid acids (entries 1–8, Table 1). The reactions with different amounts of IL-HSO4@SBA-15 were also studied in various solvents (entries 8–15, Table 1). As showed in Table 1, the model reaction with 2mol% of the catalyst proves to be optimum in terms of the yield. We used water as the solvent because it is inexpensive, non-toxic, and environmentally benign, and also, the highest dispersion of IL@SBA-15 was achieved in water. To demonstrate the diversity of the supported ionic liquids of halogen-free imidazolium hydrogensulfate, and to expand the scope of the process, the optimized conditions were applied to a series of substrates 1, and 2 as shown in Table 2 . We next explored the scope of our method in the synthesis of polyhydroquinolines 5, via the condensation of dimedone, an aldehyde and enaminone 4. In fact, encouraged by this promising result, we proceeded to further study the catalytic performance of 5 in the one-pot preparation of polyhydroquinolines. As shown in Table 3 , various types of aromatic aldehydes with electron-donating groups (entries 6–8), electron-withdrawing groups (entries 2–5) and even ortho-substituted aldehydes (entries 3, 4, 7 and 8) were cleanly and rapidly converted to the corresponding polyhydroquinolines in good to excellent yields. The results are summarized in Table 3. The catalytic activity of IL-HSO4@SBA-15 in domino Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization reactions to synthesis of bis-tetrahydro-4H-chromene 6 was also studied under the optimized conditions. When we examined the reaction under the sequential multicomponent reaction (SEQ–MCR) method, the yield was 47% after 6h. However, the yield of product 6 could reach 76% by using the novel one-step multicomponent reaction (Scheme 1 ). The possibility of recycling the IL-HSO4@SBA-15 catalyst was also studied. When the reaction was complete, the catalyst was easily separated from the products. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , the catalyst could be reused over at least seven consecutive runs without significant loss of activity. After the 11th runs, the yield decreased to 76% from the original 95%. This indicated that the ionic liquid immobilized SBA-15 catalyst was very robust and recyclable. Although, we have not still provided a certain mechanism for the one-pot preparation of the 3 and 5 using aldehyde over the IL-HSO4@SBA-15 catalyst in an experimental manner, a possible explanation was proposed in Scheme 2 . Note that, the hydrophobic nature of the ionic liquid may benefit the fast diffusion of reaction substrates to the catalytic centers in SBA-15 mesoporous channels, and also increase the Brønsted acid strength in terms of an acid site cooperativity mechanism (Scheme 2). 4 Conclusion In summary, we have introduced a powerful and water-tolerant supported Brønsted solid acid catalyst that shows remarkable catalytic activity and recyclability in multicomponent coupling synthesis of tetrahydrochromenes and hexahydroquinolines via Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization processes under green water media conditions. It is believed that the hydrophobic nature of the ionic liquid affords the efficient mass transfer of starting substrates to the active sites immobilized within SBA-15 pores, and at the same time, it might also increase the Brønsted acid strength as a result of a novel proposed acid site cooperativity mechanism. coredata.dc:description: The Brønsted acidic imidazolium-based metal-free and halogen-free ionic liquid hydrogen sulfate was immobilized on nanoporous silica SBA-15. The structures of synthesized catalysts were investigated using different characterization techniques, including FT-IR, small angle XRD, SEM, TEM and TGA. The [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 is used as an alternative to conventional catalysts in the Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization processes for the synthesis of tetrahydrochromenes and hexahydroquinoline carboxylates via a multicomponent procedure. The reaction time is reduced drastically and the reaction is progressed in an environmentally friendly way. The immobilized catalyst can be recycled without substantial loss of activity after seven runs.
coredata.dc:title: Brønsted acidic hydrogensulfate ionic liquid immobilized SBA-15: [MPIm][HSO4]@SBA-15 as an environmentally friendly, metal- and halogen-free recyclable catalyst for Knoevenagel–Michael-cyclization processes
